page.title: 01ECOLOGY OF THE SOUTH DOWNS
page.content: { { }This block covers a completely rural area of the S. Downs of great interest to botanists & conservation- ists. The N. face of the Downs is covered with rough grass, scrub and mainly deciduous trees, while the S. facing slopes are thickly planted with a mixture of conifers and deciduous trees forming the Charlton & Singleton forests, criss-crossed by many grassy footpaths and bridle ways. { }Along the top of the Downs the S. Downs Way runs through a wide stretch of flatter land, formerly covered with short downland turf but now mostly ploughed & planted with cereal crops. { }Chalk flowers, including many now rare, still grow on the northern slopes. Many species of butterflies } & insects flourish & birds & animals enjoy the quiet habitat.
